Question Text: Another term for POTS, or Plain Old Telephone Service, is _______________.
Choices:
a. Public Available Telephone Network
b. Public Switched Telephone Exchange
c. Phone Switched Transport Network
d. Public Switched Telephone Network
e. Public Available Telephone Exchange
LLM Explanation: POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service) is another term for the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). The PSTN is the traditional circuit-switched telephone network that has been in use for many decades. It is a global system of interconnected voice-oriented public telephone networks, both commercial and government-owned.

Question Text: A baud rate is a measurement of the number of ______________________.
Choices:
a. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
b. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every second
c. bits that can be sent across a telephone line every second
d. bytes that can be sent across a telephone line every minute
LLM Explanation: A baud rate measures the number of bits that can be transmitted across a telephone line every second. It represents the signaling rate or symbol rate of a communication channel.

Question Text: What system did Duke grads build that is still in use today?
Choices:
a. POTS
b. PSTN
c. USENET
d. DSL
LLM Explanation: USENET, a worldwide distributed discussion system, was created by Duke University graduate students Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis in 1979. It allows users to read and post messages to newsgroups. While not as widely used today compared to its peak, USENET is still an active system for discussion and file sharing.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet', 'https://www.britannica.com/technology/USENET', 'Kurose, J. F., & Ross, K. W. (2017). Computer networking: a top-down approach. Pearson.']

Question Text: Which device is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection?
Choices:
a. ATM
b. Modem
c. Ethernet cables
d. USENET
LLM Explanation: A modem (modulator-demodulator) is used to transfer data across a dial-up connection. It converts digital signals from a computer into analog signals that can be transmitted over telephone lines and vice versa. ATM, Ethernet cables, and USENET are not directly related to dial-up connections.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modem']

Question Text: Modems take data that computers can understand and turn them into _____ that can be transmitted over POTS.
Choices:
a. Audible wavelengths
b. Baud rates
c. Modulating electrical charges
d. PSTN
LLM Explanation: Modems convert digital data from computers into audible wavelengths or analog signals that can be transmitted over plain old telephone service (POTS) lines. The modem modulates the digital data into these audible tones for transmission and demodulates the tones back into digital data on the receiving end.

Choices:
a. Transmission 1
b. Transportation 1
c. Transmission System 1
d. Transportation System 1
LLM Explanation: T1 is short for Transmission 1. It refers to a digital transmission system that carries data at a rate of 1.544 Mbps. T1 lines are widely used for connecting networks across remote distances.

Question Text: How fast is a T1 line?
Choices:
a. 128 Mb/sec
b. 1.544 Mb/sec
c. 1 Mb/sec
d. 44.763 Mb/sec
LLM Explanation: A T1 line is a dedicated digital carrier connection supporting data rates of 1.544 Mbps (megabits per second). It is a widely used leased line option for businesses requiring high-speed connectivity. The other choices listed are incorrect - 128 Mbps corresponds more to home cable modem speeds, 1 Mbps is too slow, and 44.763 Mbps does not match any standard line rate.

Question Text: Select all statements that are true of cable internet connections.
Choices:
a. They're wireless connections
b. They're broadband connections
c. They're dial-up connections
d. They're shared bandwidth connections
LLM Explanation: Cable internet connections are broadband connections that provide high-speed internet access using the same coaxial cables that deliver cable television signals. They are not wireless connections, as they require a physical cable connection. Cable internet is also not a dial-up connection, which uses telephone lines and has much slower speeds. Cable internet connections are shared bandwidth connections, meaning that the available bandwidth is shared among all users in a particular area, which can lead to slower speeds during peak usage times.

Question Text: What are the subprotocols for PPP (Point to Point Protocol)? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. FCS
b. LCP
c. Compression
d. NCP
LLM Explanation: The two main subprotocols of PPP are:b) LCP (Link Control Protocol): Establishes, configures, and tests the data-link connection. It is responsible for negotiating authentication, encryption, and compression options.  d) NCP (Network Control Protocol): A series of protocols, each specific to a particular network layer protocol, that configure the network layer protocol parameters and facilities. Examples include IPCP (Internet Protocol Control Protocol) for IPv4 and IPv6CP for IPv6.The other options are incorrect:a) FCS (Frame Check Sequence) is a field in the PPP frame used for error detection, not a subprotocol.c) Compression is a feature that can be negotiated by LCP, but it is not a subprotocol itself.
URLs: ['Forouzan, B. A. (2012). Data Communications and Networking (5th ed.). McGraw-Hill.', 'RFC 1661: The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP). https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1661']

Question Text: What do you call the demarcation point for fiber technologies?
Choices:
a. ONT
b. FTTN
c. FTTX
d. DSLAM
LLM Explanation: ONT stands for Optical Network Terminal. It is the device installed at the customer premises that terminates the fiber optic line from the service provider and converts it into the customer's desired interface, such as Ethernet. The ONT serves as the demarcation point between the service provider's network and the customer's network for fiber technologies like FTTX (Fiber To The X).

Choices:
a. Wireless Local Area Network
b. Wireless Area Network
c. Wired Area Network
d. Wide Area Network
LLM Explanation: WAN stands for Wide Area Network. A WAN is a computer network that spans a large geographical area, such as across cities, states, or countries. It is used to connect LANs (Local Area Networks) and other types of networks together, enabling communication between computers and users in different locations.
URLs: ['Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0 (ITN)', 'CompTIA Network+ Certification Study Guide']

Question Text: In a WAN, what is the area between a demarcation point and the ISP's core network known as?
Choices:
a. a local loop
b. a Local Area Network
c. A local link
d. An access point
LLM Explanation: In a Wide Area Network (WAN), the area between the demarcation point (the point where the customer's responsibility for the network ends and the service provider's begins) and the Internet Service Provider's (ISP) core network is known as the local loop. The local loop, also called the 'last mile', is the physical link or circuit that connects the customer premises to the ISP's nearest point of presence or central office.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/switches/catalyst-6500-series-switches/white_paper_c11-728554.html']

Question Text: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a ______________.
Choices:
a. port forwarding VPN
b. one-to-many VPN
c. data link VPN
d. site-to-site VPN
LLM Explanation: A point-to-point VPN is also known as a site-to-site VPN. It is a type of VPN that connects two specific locations, such as two branch offices of a company, over a public network like the Internet. The VPN creates a secure, encrypted tunnel between the two sites, allowing them to communicate as if they were on the same private network.

Question Text: Who handles sending data from one site to another?
Choices:
a. T-carrier line
b. CTO
c. ISP
d. VPN
LLM Explanation: An Internet Service Provider (ISP) is responsible for handling the transmission of data from one site to another over the Internet. ISPs own and maintain the infrastructure, such as routers, servers, and fiber optic cables, that enable data to be sent and received between different networks and devices connected to the Internet.

Question Text: How many address fields does an 802.11 header contain?
LLM Explanation: The 802.11 header contains 3 address fields. Address 1 is the receiver address (RA), Address 2 is the transmitter address (TA), and Address 3 is used for filtering by the receiver. In some cases, there is a fourth address field present, but the standard 802.11 header has 3 address fields.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']

Choices:
a. a collision domain
b. a point-to-point wireless connection
c. an example of an ad-hoc network
d. Individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network
LLM Explanation: Wireless channels are individual, smaller sections of the overall frequency band used by a wireless network. The overall frequency band is divided into these smaller channels to allow multiple devices to communicate simultaneously without interfering with each other. Each channel operates on a specific frequency within the band.
URLs: ['CompTIA Network+ Certification All-in-One Exam Guide, Seventh Edition (Exam N10-007) by Mike Meyers', 'Networking Essentials: A CompTIA Network+ N10-007 Textbook by Jeffrey S. Beasley']

Question Text: Which of the following frequencies do wireless networks typically operate on? Select all that apply.
LLM Explanation: Wireless networks typically operate on the 2.4GHz and 5GHz frequency bands. The 2.4GHz band is the most common, supporting 802.11b, 802.11g, and 802.11n standards. The 5GHz band is used by 802.11a, 802.11n, and 802.11ac standards, offering higher speeds and less interference. The other frequencies mentioned (1.544GHz and 88MHz) are not used for standard Wi-Fi networks.
URLs: ['IEEE 802.11 Wireless LAN Standards: https://www.ieee802.org/11/', 'Wi-Fi Alliance: https://www.wi-fi.org/discover-wi-fi/wi-fi-standards', 'Cisco Wireless Networking Basics: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/small-business/resource-center/networking/wireless-network.html']

Question Text: WPA3 was built with the intention of replacing which protocol?
Choices:
a. WPA2
b. WLAN
c. WEP
d. IEEE 802.11
LLM Explanation: WPA3 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 3) was developed as a replacement for WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2). WPA3 aims to enhance wireless security by introducing new features such as improved encryption, protection against brute-force attacks, and more secure handshakes between devices and access points. While WPA2 has been widely used and provided significant improvements over the older WEP protocol, WPA3 is designed to address the vulnerabilities and security concerns that have emerged over time with WPA2.
URLs: ['Wi-Fi Alliance. (2018). Wi-Fi Alliance® introduces Wi-Fi CERTIFIED WPA3™ security. https://www.wi-fi.org/news-events/newsroom/wi-fi-alliance-introduces-wi-fi-certified-wpa3-security', 'Cisco. (2021). Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3). https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/wireless/what-is-wpa3.html']

Question Text: An 802.11 frame contains a number of fields. Which field describes the version of 802.11 that is being used?
Choices:
a. Sequence control
b. Frame control
c. Address
d. Duration
LLM Explanation: The Frame Control field in an 802.11 frame contains information that defines the type of 802.11 MAC frame and provides information necessary for the following fields to understand how to process the MAC frame. This includes the Protocol Version subfield which is used to indicate the version of the 802.11 protocol.
URLs: ['802.11-2016 - IEEE Standard for Information technology—Telecommunications and information exchange between systems Local and metropolitan area networks—Specific requirements - Part 11: Wireless LAN Medium Access Control (MAC) and Physical Layer (PHY) Specifications', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/802.11_Frame_Types']
